docs.lead_paragraph: ORLANDO, Fla. -- Representative Alan Grayson could have headed straight for the sign that said ''Health Care Hero.'' Instead, he held back, smiling and bouncing in his zippered size 13 boots, letting the cheers crescendo like Bruce Springsteen before an encore. When Mr. Grayson, a first-term Democrat, reached the 75 supporters awaiting him at the airport here on Friday, he was unabashedly triumphant. ''It's not enough to be No. 1 in your military expenditures, it's not enough to be No. 1 in the number of countries around the would that you occupy,'' he said. ''We have to be No. 1 in health care.''

headline.main: Six Districts, Two Sides, One Weekend: The Vulnerable Victor

docs.abstract: Rep Alan Grayson, Florida Democrat who voted in favor of health care reform legislation, greets supporters at airport in Orlando before primary; photo (M)
docs.snippet: ORLANDO, Fla. -- Representative Alan Grayson could have headed straight for the sign that said ''Health Care Hero.'' Instead, he held back, smiling and bouncing in his zippered size 13 boots, letting the cheers crescendo like Bruce Springsteen before...

docs.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON - Congress has voted, President Obama will hold a last signing ceremony on Tuesday, and still, Americans are struggling to make sense of the health care debate - what it means for them and their families, for businesses and the economy, for states, for lawmakers in the November elections, for Mr. Obama and his presidency, for the nation's future, and in a most elemental way, for the future of civil democracy. People surprised by the visceral - and in some cases vicious and violent - reactions to approval of the legislation have not had the benefit of months of e-mail from readers of The New York Times and this blog. Passions often ran high in these messages.

headline.main: An Overhaul Passes, The Vitriol Lives On

docs.abstract: Prescriptions blog column on vitriolic reactions to approval of health care reform legislation, which has become touchstone for larger disagreements and deeper divisions in increasingly fractured society; recap of discourse over past year (M)
docs.snippet: WASHINGTON - Congress has voted, President Obama will hold a last signing ceremony on Tuesday, and still, Americans are struggling to make sense of the health care debate - what it means for them and their families, for businesses and the economy,...

docs.lead_paragraph: PEORIA, Ill. -- The youngest member of Congress came home this weekend to hugs. Hugs, then more hugs. ''Thank you for making time to do this,'' one woman said during her hug, as Representative Aaron Schock stepped inside a church gymnasium to shoot free throws for charity. ''And thank you,'' she added quickly, ''for your vote on health care.''

headline.main: Six Districts, Two Sides, One Weekend: The Conservative Freshman

docs.abstract: Rep Aaron Schock, freshman Illinois Republican, encounters no criticism among constituents in Peoria of his vote against health care reform bill in advance of primary; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: In politics, as in sports, the thrill of victory sometimes pales alongside the agony of defeat. In 2010, Democrats remain on track to experience both. Achievement of their decades-long quest for comprehensive health care legislation left Congressional leaders and White House aides jubilant. It broke, at least temporarily, the psychology of failure that threatened President Obama's administration as it had burdened President George W. Bush's tenure.

headline.main: Health Care Cheers Democrats, but Grim November May Still Lie Ahead

docs.abstract: John Harwood The Caucus column on likelihood, despite Democratic victory in passage of health care reform bill and in wake of higher rates of unemployment, that number of Democrats in Congress will drop after November election; photo (M)
